resources.string: \nThieboudienne (ceebu Jen) is the Senegalese Rice and fish, it is also known as Riz gras in Cote d\'Ivoire, Burkina Faso, Guinea, and other countries in West Africa.\nIn Nigeria and Ghana, a similar recipe is called Jollof Rice. The recipe is made from rice, fish, tomato sauce, and other vegetables.

4 cups of rice
 2-3 Fishes of your choice (salmon or red snapper))
 4 fresh tomatoes, mashed
 3 tablespoons of tomato paste
 1 bunch parsley, crushed
 1 large carrot, peeled and chopped medium
 2 potatoes, peeled and chopped
 1 large onion, chopped
 4 cloves garlic, finely chopped
 2 eggplants, peeled
 1 cabbage, cut into 4 pieces
 200 ml peanut oil
 2 bouillon cubes or Maggi cubes
 4 bay leaves
 4 hot peppers
 1 tablespoon black pepperv Salt
 4 okras
 1 tablespoon Yété, optional
 1 tablespoons nététou (if available)
 1.5l hot water

Step 1: Preparing the fish and its stuffing:
 To make your rice easier to cook, soak it in hot water for 20 minutes and wash it several times with cool water. Wash the fishes and divide them into medium pieces. Then mix the parsley with half of the garlic, some ground hot pepper, add some salt, and half of a bouillon cube. Mixing the stuffing can be done in a mortar and pestle or by using a food processor. Use a knife to make holes in each fish, and then insert the stuffing into the holes.
 Step 2: Making the tomato sauce.
 In a large cooking pot, heat the oil. Then, add onions, tomatoes, tomato paste, garlic, and black pepper. Stir -fry for about 15 minutes over medium heat. You can then add the fish into the tomato sauce. But some people prefer to fry the fish in advance. Add one bouillon cube, the bay leaves, and 1 cup water to the tomato sauce. Let that simmer until the fish pieces are half-cooked; this may take 15 minutes or less.
 Step 3
 Remove the fish from the tomato sauce and set it aside. Now add all vegetables to the pot except the okras. Add another cup of water and cook the vegetables until they are all very tender. It may take 20 to 30 minutes. When the vegetables are ready, remove them from the pot and set them aside. Then add the okra with more water and bring the soup to boil.
 When the okras are ready, you can remove them and add the rice. Cook the rice over low heat; you might need to turn it often so that all sides get cooked. When your thieboudienne is ready to serve, place the rice in a large dish and arrange the vegetables and fish on top.
 Enjoy!

20 large Okra pods
 2 cups or 200gr green vegetable (spinach, ugwu/fluted pumpkin leaves, kale, or shoko)
 2 large red bell peppers
 2 Scotch bonnet peppers
 1 Onions
 1 teaspoon cameroon pepper(optional)
 Dried fish
 Fresh large prawns(shrimps)
 Fresh fish(mackerel)
 1 cooking spoonful (half cup) Palm oil (palm oil) 
 1 handful (half cup) locust bean/Iru/ogiri(optional)
 half cup Crayfish (ground)
 Seasoning powder or cubes to taste
 Salt to taste
 Stockfish
 Note: This seafood okra soup is quite simple and contains a few kinds of seafood; but feel free to add any other seafood of your choice, such as crabs, lobster, squid, calamari, and periwinkles.
\nSeafood okra soup is one out of many okra soup recipes. Okra as a vegetable is one of the most versatile pods in African cuisine.

1 cup Ground Egusi 
 ½ cup palm oil
 Dried fish, smoked fish, or stockfish, to taste
 200g Beef or goat meat, chopped into small size
 150 g chicken (optional)
 2 onions, sliced
 2 cloves garlic, chopped
 ½ tsp thyme leaves
 1 tsp curry powder
 1 bouillon cube or Maggi
 1 large tomato, mashed or blended
 1 tsp tomato paste
 Fresh pepper with or substituted for grounded dried pepper
 Spinach leaves, pumpkin or bitter leaf, (or any leaf) 
 1 tbsp ground Crayfish or ground dried shrimp
 ½ tsp chili powder
 Salt, to taste
 Water

1 cup Ground Egusi 
 ½ cup palm oil
 150 g chicken (optional)
 2 onions, sliced
 2 cloves garlic, chopped
 ½ tsp thyme leaves
 1 tsp curry powder
 1 bouillon cube or Maggi
 1 large tomato, mashed or blended
 1 tsp tomato paste
 ½ tsp chili powder
 Salt, to taste
 Water
 Dried fish, smoked fish, or stockfish, to taste
 200g Beef or goat meat, chopped into small size
 1 tbsp ground Crayfish or ground dried shrimp
 Fresh pepper with or substituted for grounded dried pepper
 Spinach leaves, pumpkin, or bitter leaf, (or any leaf)

1 cup Ground Egusi 
 ½ cup palm oil
 150 g chicken (optional)
 2 onions, sliced
 2 cloves garlic, chopped
 ½ tsp thyme leaves
 1 tsp curry powder
 1 bouillon cube or Maggi
 1 large tomato, mashed or blended
 1 tsp tomato paste
 ½ tsp chili powder
 Water
 Salt, to taste
 Dried fish, smoked fish, or stockfish, to taste
 200g Beef or goat meat, chopped into small size
 1 tbsp ground Crayfish or ground dried shrimp
 Fresh pepper with or substituted for grounded dried pepper
 Spinach leaves, pumpkin, or bitter leaf, (or any leaf)

Adwnene 1.3 lb
 Superku 0.3 lb 
 Herring 0.4 lb
 Guinea fowl 1.5 lb
 Palm cream 1.6lb can
 Ginger 66 grams
 Prekese (Aidan fruit) 75 grams
 Snails 0.5 lb Periwinkle 80 grams
 Mushrooms 70g
 Onions 2 large
 Tomatoes 3 large
 1 Maggie shrimp tablet
 Salt and pepper to taste
 Water 4 quarts

Any meat, or fish of your choice
 Potato greens/ leaves
 Red palm oil
 Seasons

Frying oil
 1/4 cup of oil
 Salt to taste
 2 headless cassava fish clean
 1 tablespoon of ginger
 1 teaspoon of black pepper
 Fresh cooking herbs: thyme (optional)
 1 pack (about 250g pack) of attieke
 2 medium tomatoes diced
 1 medium onion diced
 1/2 green bell pepper finely diced
 Msg-free bouillon powder (to taste) 
 1 habanero pepper diced finely (can use less if you are not a hot pepper person)

1 cup water
 2 bay leaves
 ½ teaspoon ginger
 2 onions, each sliced ¼ inch thick
 4 cloves garlic, minced
 5 tablespoons oil (preferably peanut) 
 1 whole chicken, cut into 8 pieces
 1 tablespoon white wine vinegar
 3 tablespoons Dijon mustard
 ½ cup green olives, pitted and sliced
 2 chicken bouillon cubes, dissolved in 1 cup of water
 2 habanero peppers, seeded and sliced very thinly (wear gloves) 
 1 teaspoon pepper ½ cup fresh lemon juice and 1 sliced lemon
